Starters.name: Samosa
preparation_steps: Make a dough with flour and water.
Prepare the filling with potatoes, peas, and spices.
Shape the dough into triangles, fill with the mixture, and seal.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Starters.cultural_significance: A popular Indian snack, often served with chutney.

Starters.name: Paneer Tikka
preparation_steps: Marinate paneer and vegetables in yogurt and spices.
Skewer and grill until charred.
Serve with mint chutney.
Starters.cultural_significance: A favorite appetizer, often enjoyed at parties.

Starters.name: Dhokla
ingredients: Tempering: mustard seeds, curry leaves, green chilies
preparation_steps: Mix gram flour, yogurt, and spices to form a batter.
Steam until firm.
Temper with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and green chilies.
Starters.cultural_significance: A soft and spongy Gujarati snack, perfect for breakfast or tea.

Starters.name: Aloo Tikki
preparation_steps: Mix mashed potatoes with spices and shape into patties.
Shallow fry until golden brown.
Serve with chutney or yogurt.
Starters.cultural_significance: A street food favorite, often served as chaat.

Starters.name: Pakora
preparation_steps: Make a batter with gram flour, spices, and water.
Dip vegetables into the batter and deep fry.
Serve with chutney.
Starters.cultural_significance: A popular monsoon snack enjoyed with tea.

Starters.name: Hara Bhara Kebab
preparation_steps: Mash all ingredients together and form patties.
Shallow fry until crisp.
Serve with green chutney.
Starters.cultural_significance: A healthy and tasty vegetarian kebab.

Starters.name: Pani Puri
preparation_steps: Make and fry puris until crispy.
Prepare spiced potato filling.
Fill puris with potatoes, chickpeas, and spicy mint water.
Starters.cultural_significance: A famous street food snack enjoyed across India.

Starters.name: Mirchi Bajji
preparation_steps: Slit green chilies and remove seeds.
Dip in gram flour batter and deep fry.
Serve with chutney.
Starters.cultural_significance: A popular spicy snack from Andhra Pradesh.

Starters.name: Dahi Puri
preparation_steps: Fill puris with mashed potatoes and yogurt.
Drizzle with chutneys and spices.
Serve immediately.
Starters.cultural_significance: A variation of Pani Puri, with a creamy and tangy flavor.

Starters.name: Momos
preparation_steps: Make a dough with flour and water.
Prepare a filling with cabbage, carrot, and soy sauce.
Fill and shape dumplings, then steam until cooked.
Starters.cultural_significance: Originally from Tibet, momos are now a beloved Indian street food.

Main Course.name: Biryani
preparation_steps: Fry onions until golden.
Add marinated chicken and cook.
Layer rice and cook on low heat until done.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A fragrant rice dish with Persian influences, widely popular in India.

Main Course.name: Butter Chicken
preparation_steps: Cook chicken in spices and tomato puree.
Add cream and butter, simmer until thick.
Serve with naan or rice.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A creamy and rich dish that originated in Delhi.

Main Course.name: Dal Makhani
preparation_steps: Soak lentils and kidney beans overnight and cook until soft.
Prepare a tomato-based gravy and mix with cooked lentils.
Simmer with butter and cream for a rich texture.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A Punjabi specialty, often paired with naan or jeera rice.

Main Course.name: Rogan Josh
ingredients: Spices (red chili powder, garam masala, fennel seeds)
preparation_steps: Cook mutton with onions and spices.
Add yogurt and slow cook until tender.
Serve with rice or naan.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A signature Kashmiri dish known for its deep red color and rich flavor.

Main Course.name: Palak Paneer
preparation_steps: Blanch and puree spinach.
Sauté onions, tomatoes, and spices, then mix with spinach puree.
Add paneer cubes and simmer.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A nutritious and flavorful dish, rich in iron and protein.

Main Course.name: Chole Bhature
ingredients: For Bhature: all-purpose flour, yogurt, salt
preparation_steps: Cook chickpeas in a spiced onion-tomato gravy.
Prepare dough for Bhature and deep fry.
Serve hot together.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A popular Punjabi dish, often enjoyed as a weekend treat.

Main Course.name: Masala Dosa
preparation_steps: Soak and grind rice and dal to make dosa batter.
Prepare spiced mashed potato filling.
Cook dosa on a pan, fill with potato mixture, and fold.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A crispy and savory South Indian breakfast staple.

Main Course.name: Baingan Bharta
preparation_steps: Roast eggplants until charred, then mash.
Sauté onions, tomatoes, and spices, then mix with mashed eggplant.
Cook until fragrant and serve with roti.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A smoky and flavorful dish from North India.

Main Course.name: Pongal
preparation_steps: Cook rice and moong dal together.
Temper with ghee, black pepper, and cumin.
Garnish with cashews and serve.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A comforting dish, often prepared during the Pongal festival.

Main Course.name: Sarson da Saag with Makki di Roti
ingredients: For Roti: maize flour, water, salt
preparation_steps: Boil and mash mustard greens and spinach.
Cook with onions, tomatoes, and spices.
Prepare and cook maize flour rotis on a griddle.
Serve together with butter.
Main Course.cultural_significance: A winter delicacy from Punjab, best enjoyed with butter and jaggery.

Desserts.name: Gulab Jamun
preparation_steps: Make dough from khoya, flour, and baking powder.
Shape into balls and fry until golden.
Soak in sugar syrup.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A classic Indian sweet often served at festivals and celebrations.

Desserts.name: Rasgulla
preparation_steps: Boil milk and curdle with lemon juice.
Knead the chenna into smooth balls.
Boil in sugar syrup until spongy.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A famous Bengali sweet known for its soft and spongy texture.

Desserts.name: Jalebi
preparation_steps: Make a batter with flour, yogurt, and baking soda.
Pipe into spirals and deep fry until crisp.
Soak in sugar syrup and serve.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A crispy, sweet treat often enjoyed during festivals.

Desserts.name: Kheer
preparation_steps: Cook rice in milk until soft and thick.
Add sugar, nuts, and cardamom powder.
Simmer and serve warm or chilled.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A traditional rice pudding, often prepared during religious ceremonies.

Desserts.name: Mysore Pak
preparation_steps: Make sugar syrup by boiling sugar and water.
Add besan and ghee gradually, stirring continuously.
Cook until mixture thickens and sets, then cut into pieces.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A rich, buttery sweet that originated in the royal kitchens of Mysore.

Desserts.name: Modak
preparation_steps: Make a dough with rice flour and hot water.
Prepare filling with coconut, jaggery, and cardamom.
Shape into dumplings and steam until cooked.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A favorite sweet of Lord Ganesha, often made during Ganesh Chaturthi.

Desserts.name: Malpua
preparation_steps: Make a batter with flour, milk, and sugar.
Fry small pancakes until golden brown.
Soak in sugar syrup and serve.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A festive delicacy, often prepared during Holi and Diwali.

Desserts.name: Puran Poli
preparation_steps: Cook chana dal and mix with jaggery and cardamom to make a filling.
Make a dough with whole wheat flour and roll into discs.
Fill with sweet mixture, roll out, and cook with ghee.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A traditional sweet flatbread, prepared during special occasions.

Desserts.name: Sandesh
preparation_steps: Curdle milk with lemon juice to make chenna.
Knead chenna until smooth, mix with sugar and cardamom.
Shape into small pieces and refrigerate.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A delicate Bengali sweet, known for its soft and melt-in-the-mouth texture.

Desserts.name: Payasam
preparation_steps: Cook rice or vermicelli in coconut milk.
Add jaggery and cardamom powder.
Garnish with fried cashews and raisins.
Desserts.cultural_significance: A South Indian dessert, often served in temples and festivals.

Beverages.name: Masala Chai
Beverages.steps: Boil water and spices. Add tea leaves. Add milk and sugar. Simmer and strain.
Beverages.culture: A staple beverage in Indian households, often enjoyed during morning and evening.

Beverages.name: Lassi
Beverages.steps: Blend yogurt with water and flavorings until smooth. Serve chilled.
Beverages.culture: Traditional Punjabi drink served during summers for refreshment.

Beverages.name: Filter Coffee
Beverages.steps: Brew coffee in a filter. Boil milk. Mix both and serve hot.
Beverages.culture: Popular in Tamil Nadu and Karnataka, typically served in steel tumblers.

Beverages.name: Tender Coconut Water
Beverages.steps: Chill and serve directly from the coconut shell.
Beverages.culture: Natural energy drink, widely consumed in tropical regions.

Beverages.name: Buttermilk
Beverages.steps: Blend curd with water and spices. Serve chilled.
Beverages.culture: Cooling drink for summers, often served after meals.

Beverages.name: Thandai
Beverages.steps: Grind ingredients into a paste. Mix with chilled milk. Strain and serve.
Beverages.culture: Specially made during Holi festival for its cooling properties.

Beverages.name: Jaljeera
Beverages.steps: Blend all ingredients with water. Chill and serve.
Beverages.culture: Tangy drink served as an appetizer or digestive.

Beverages.name: Sugarcane Juice
Beverages.steps: Crush sugarcane and extract juice. Add lemon and ginger. Serve chilled.
Beverages.culture: Street-side favorite drink, especially in summer.

Beverages.name: Sol Kadhi
Beverages.steps: Soak kokum. Mix with coconut milk and spices. Chill and serve.
Beverages.culture: Digestive drink from coastal Maharashtra, often consumed after meals.

Beverages.name: Aam Panna
Beverages.steps: Boil mangoes. Blend with spices and chill. Serve with ice.
Beverages.culture: Summer cooler made from green mangoes, helps beat the heat.
